 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today but no episodes of sinus
   pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - f/u heme/onc on need for neupogen
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung, complicated by SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and electrolyte disturbances. She is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient's condition is complex, with multiple potential medical complications. Some of the key concerns include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with increased RR and PaO2/FiO2 ratio indicating respiratory acidosis. The presence of bibasilar infiltrates on CXR suggests VAP, which is a common complication in critically ill patients.
2. Electrolyte disturbances: The patient has hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, which may be related to hypoaldosteronism, SIADH, and Type IV RTA. The patient's potassium levels are slightly elevated, but no episodes of sinus pauses on EKG have occurred.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol levels are not reported, but the physician suspects that the patient may have adrenal insufficiency, which is a common complication in patients with small cell carcinoma.
4. SVC syndrome: The patient's SVC syndrome is incomplete, with near-complete occlusion of the brachiocephalic veins. This may be related to the patient's small cell carcinoma.
5. Pleural effusion: The patient's pleural effusion is exudative, with a high LDH effusion/serum ratio. The patient's malignant effusion is a concern.
6. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax appears to have resolved, but the physician is concerned about the possibility of recurrence.
7. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is suspected to be malignant, with low-voltage EKG and no signs of electrical alternans.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC is trending downwards, possibly due to chemotherapy. The patient's leukopenia in the setting of infection is concerning.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is normocytic, with a stable Hct. The patient's LDH is elevated, but bilirubin is normal. ACD is possible given the patient's malignancy.

The patient's medication regimen includes:

1. Propofol for sedation
2. Heparin for DVT prophylaxis
3. Pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
4. Vancomycin for MRSA VAP
5. Cefepime for MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
6. Hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
7. Kayexalate for hyperkalemia
8. Hydralazine for hypertension

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Weaning from mechanical ventilation
2. Titration of propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain management
3. Resend sputum culture
4. Continue to monitor blood, urine, and sputum cultures
5. Trend WBC and hematocrit
6. Continue to monitor electrolyte levels and adjust medications as needed
7. Consider radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
8. F/u cardiology and endocrinology recs
9. Monitor for signs of SVC syndrome and pericardial effusion

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and close monitoring and management are necessary to address the multiple potential medical complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure.
* He is mechanically ventilated via ETT and remains sedated.
* He has a history of COPD, and new RLL and LLL infiltrates are concerning for VAP.
* He has a right pleural effusion, which has resolved, and a right pneumothorax, which is being treated with a chest tube.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on the background of COPD.
* He will continue to receive mechanical ventilation, monitor ABG, and await culture results.
* He will receive empirical antimicrobials for suspected VAP.
* He will undergo chemotherapy and XRT for his small cell carcinoma.
* His hypotension is attributed to adrenal insufficiency, hypovolemia, and SIADH, and he will continue to receive steroids.
* His hypertension will be monitored, and his fluid balance will be managed to prevent fluid overload.

**Potential Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: continued respiratory failure can lead to further decline in oxygenation and ventilation, and may require escalation of ventilator support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* VAP: failure to treat VAP promptly and effectively can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and increased mortality.
* Renal failure: the patient's rising creatinine and falling urine output suggest potential pre-renal failure, which can be exacerbated by fluid overload and may require further investigation and management.
* Sinus dysrhythmia: the patient's sinus pauses may be related to his hilar mass or involvement of the conduction system, and may require further monitoring and management.
* Metabolic acidosis: the patient's resolving metabolic acidosis may be related to RTA secondary to hypoaldosteronism, and continued monitoring is necessary to ensure resolution.
* Anemia: the patient's stable anemia may require further investigation to determine the underlying cause and potential treatment options.
* Nutritional support: the patient's NPO status and potential need for TF may require further evaluation and management to ensure adequate nutrition and hydration.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator support as necessary.
* Continue to manage his fluid balance to prevent fluid overload and optimize his renal function.
* Continue to monitor his electrolytes and adjust his management accordingly.
* Consider re-imaging if his mental status does not improve with sedation discontinuation.
* Monitor his nutritional status and consider TF if necessary.
* Continue to manage his VAP and adjust his antimicrobial therapy as necessary.
* Consider a cardiology consultation to further evaluate his sinus dysrhythmia and potential conduction system involvement.

 The progressive interstitial pulmonary abnormality and right
   pleural effusion probably due to pulmonary edema. More severe
   consolidative abnormalities at both lung bases are also concerning for
   pneumonia. Right apical pleural tube in place. No pneumothorax. ET tube
   and nasogastric tube in standard placements. Heart size normal,
   unchanged. The bulk of the large right upper lobe mass has decreased
   over the past several days.
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today but no episodes of sinus
   pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - f/u heme/onc on need for neupogen
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female admitted to the ICU for small cell lung carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome, airway compromise, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She has been receiving radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's condition has been unstable, with worsening respiratory failure, metabolic acidosis, and hyperkalemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, and the development of VAP is a significant concern.
2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a history of pneumothorax, and the chest tube is still in place to prevent recurrence.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a suspected malignant pericardial effusion, which may require percutaneous drainage or surgical intervention.
4. SVC syndrome: The patient has incomplete occlusion of the SVC, which may lead to further complications, such as cardiac tamponade or respiratory distress.
5. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is worsening, and she may require further interventions, such as non-invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to hypoaldosteronism, and further management is needed to correct this condition.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia is likely due to hypoaldosteronism, and further management is needed to correct this condition.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to chemotherapy, but it may also be a sign of infection or inflammation.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease or bleeding, and further management is needed to correct this condition.
10. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely due to underlying disease, and further management is needed to control this condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider further interventions, such as non-invasive ventilation or ECMO, if necessary.
2. Manage the patient's metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia with further interventions, such as diuretics and potassium-wasting medications.
3. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and consider further evaluation for infection or inflammation.
4. Manage the patient's anemia with further interventions, such as blood transfusions or erythropoietin therapy.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hypertension and consider further interventions, such as antihypertensive medications or lifestyle modifications.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as CT scans or echocardiograms, to evaluate the patient's SVC syndrome and pericardial effusion.
7. Consider further interventions, such as percutaneous drainage or surgical intervention, to manage the patient's pericardial effusion.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider further evaluation for neurological complications.
9. Consider further interventions, such as antiepileptics or sedatives, to manage the patient's neurological symptoms.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust management as needed to ensure optimal care.

 Stable appearances with extensive juxtamediastinal right opacity,
   probable right lung lymphangitis and bilateral lower lobe airspace
   opacities with left lower lobe atelectasis. No pneumothorax.
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today but no episodes of sinus
   pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - f/u heme/onc on need for neupogen
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

The patient has a history of small cell lung carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and pneumothorax, which may contribute to prolonged respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular: The patient has sinus pauses on telemetry, which may be related to worsening pericardial effusion or vagally mediated. The patient's heart rate (HR) is 114 bpm, and blood pressure (BP) is 144/70 mmHg.
3. Renal: The patient has worsening renal function, with creatinine levels increasing from 1.0 to 1.6 mg/dL. The patient has Type IV RTA, likely due to hypoaldosteronism, and may have prerenal azotemia.
4. Hematology: The patient has anemia, normocytic, and leukocytosis, trending downwards possibly due to chemotherapy. The patient's platelet count is 307 K/uL.
5. Infections: The patient has a history of small cell lung carcinoma and is at risk for VAP, MRSA, and pseudomonas infections. The patient's sputum culture grew 4+ GNR, 2+ yeast, and 2+ GPC.
6. Fluid and electrolyte: The patient has hyponatremia, improving with Na 140 today, and hyperkalemia, which may be due to hypoaldosteronism. The patient's potassium level is 5.3 mmol/L.
7. Endocrine: The patient has hypoaldosteronism, likely contributing to Type IV RTA, and may have adrenal insufficiency.
8. Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of small bowel obstruction and has received chemotherapy, which may have contributed to gastrointestinal symptoms.
9. Neurological: The patient has a history of cerebral aneurysm repair and has a number of chronic changes on head CT. The patient's mental status is difficult to assess due to chronic changes on head CT.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current health status include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to ongoing hypoxic respiratory failure, and the patient may require increased ventilatory support.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's sinus pauses may worsen, and the patient may develop other cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
3. Renal failure: The patient's worsening renal function may lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Infections: The patient's risk for VAP, MRSA, and pseudomonas infections is high, and the patient may develop sepsis or septic shock.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hyperkalemia and hyponatremia may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or seizures.
6. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's hypoaldosteronism may worsen, leading to adrenal insufficiency, which can cause hypotension, electrolyte imbalance, and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of small bowel obstruction and chemotherapy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Neurological deterioration: The patient's chronic changes on head CT may worsen, leading to neurological deterioration, such as seizures or stroke.

In summary, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, renal failure, infections, electrolyte imbalance, adrenal insufficiency, gastrointestinal bleeding, and neurological deterioration.

 The progressive interstitial pulmonary abnormality and right
   pleural effusion probably due to pulmonary edema. More severe
   consolidative abnormalities at both lung bases are also concerning for
   pneumonia. Right apical pleural tube in place. No pneumothorax. ET tube
   and nasogastric tube in standard placements. Heart size normal,
   unchanged. The bulk of the large right upper lobe mass has decreased
   over the past several days.
   [**8-26**] Pleural fluid path/cytology- Rare cells are highlighted by TTF-1;
   however, these cells are not cytologically atypical and may represent
   non-specific reactivity
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Continues to have mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis despite increasing RR yesterday.  Peak pressures
   in the high 38-40 and plat pressures of 30 last night so decreased TV
   and increased RR to maintain same MV of 12 but to decrease airway
   pressures. Pressure decreased slightly with these changes with plat of
   25.  Her oxygenation was worse last night with saturation decreased to
   91%.  Her PEEP was increased.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine to cover MRSA
   VAP
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Will need to touch base with heme/onc
   and rad/onc regarding plans for XRT or more chemo.
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   - IP checked Y stent placement on xray and looks the same, if continued
   problems with high pressures will consider future bronch
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol for almost 24
   hours and continues to not follow commands.  She does withdraw from
   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - started neupogen yesterday with plan for 10 day course
   - will discuss with heme/onc and rad/onc their plans for future
   chemo/radiation
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Suspect
   chemo is cause although prerenal as well based on FeNa of 0.3.  RTA may
   also play a role.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - f/u renal recs, plan to spin urine to look for sediment and casts
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - check vanc level
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved with Na 140 today. Unclear etiology on
   admission as appeared to be mixed picture of SIADH plus
   hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA.  However now thought by
   endocrine that pt was not adrenally insufficient or hypoaldo.  There
   may be some contribution of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney
   perfusion.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 150
   cc q4hrs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to Type IV RTA although unclear
   etiology.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - started neupogen yesterday with plan for 10 day course
   - will discuss with heme/onc and rad/onc their plans for future
   chemo/radiation
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Suspect
   chemo is cause although prerenal as well based on FeNa of 0.3.  RTA may
   also play a role.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - f/u renal recs, plan to spin urine to look for sediment and casts
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - check vanc level
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved with Na 140 today. Unclear etiology on
   admission as appeared to be mixed picture of SIADH plus
   hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA.  However now thought by
   endocrine that pt was not adrenally insufficient or hypoaldo.  There
   may be some contribution of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney
   perfusion.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 150
   cc q4hrs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to Type IV RTA although unclear
   etiology.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma, complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She was admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure with mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, likely due to underlying COPD, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, and atelectasis/consolidation at bilateral bases.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic with a regular rhythm and pronounced S2 at the apex, likely due to underlying cardiac disease and chemotherapy.
* Renal: Acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, likely due to chemotherapy with carboplatin and possible prerenal factors.
* Electrolyte: Hyponatremia resolved, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, likely due to Type IV RTA and possible SVC obstruction.
* Hematological: Leukocytosis trending downwards possibly due to chemotherapy, with a WBC count of 6.0 x 10^9/L.
* Neurological: Altered mental status with possible seizure activity, likely due to underlying cancer and chemotherapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise:

1. Respiratory: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and heart failure.
3. Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Electrolyte: Hyperkalemia, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis.
5. Hematological: Leukopenia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.
6. Neurological: Seizures, cerebral edema, and increased intracranial pressure.
7. Infection: Sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Consider antibiotics for possible VAP or other pulmonary infections.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider cardiology consultation if needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management and medication dosing accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medication dosing and fluid management accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's hematological status closely and consider hematological consultation if needed.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider neurology consultation if needed.
8. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and DVT prophylaxis.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust medication dosing and fluid management accordingly.

Note: This summary is based on the information provided in the progress note and is intended to be a general overview of the patient's condition and potential medical complications. It is not a substitute for a thorough medical evaluation and treatment plan.

   58 yof with new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma  with SVC syndrome

 multifactorisl, primarily due to extrinsic and

   background of COPD(?).  Also evidence for new RLL and LLL
   (retrocardiac) infiltrates, concerning for pneumonai (VAP) -->
   empirical antimicrobials.  Continue mechanical ventilation, montior
   ABG.  Monitor sputum, await culture.  Hope to eventually work towards
   SBT and extubation once completes VAP treatment and completes chemoRx
   and XRT.

   antimicrobials.  Monitor.
   MENTAL STATUS
 very slow to awken, now off Propofol >24 hrs.  Repeat
   head CT unrevealing for new pathology.  MRI not possible due to
   presence of intracranial surgical clips.  Underlying seizure disorder
   (on kepra) --> Plan EEG (continuous) to assess for non-convulsive
   status epilepticus.  LP for CSF analysis (concern for carcinomatous
   meningitis).  Consider Neurological Consultation.  [**Month (only) 11**] be toxic
   metabolic.

   chemotherapy, continue XRT.

   expanded.  No evidence for air leak.
   SMALL CELL CA -- demonstating clinical response to XRT and
   chemotherapy.   Radiation Oncology and Oncology services involve
   appreciate recommendations and guidance.  Monitor for tumor lysis.
   Need to better define prognosis.
   PERICARDIAL EFFUSION -- no evidence of tamponade on exam
 continue to
   monitor.
   HYPONATREMIA -- improved.  Attributed to adrenal insufficiency,
   hypaldosteronism, SIADH --> possibly a mixture.  Continue steroids.
   HYPERTENSION
 monitor BP.  Maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg
   FLUIDS -- positive fluid balance, likely related to chemotherapy
   agents.  However, appears pre-renal --> continue net hydration.
   Monitor I/O.
   RENAL FAILURE -- rising creatinine, falling urine output.  Possible
   pre-renal, possibly related to chemotherapy and recent contrast dye.
   Monitor urine output, BUN, creatinine.
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS  -- persistent, mild
 could be RTA secondary to
   hypoaldosteronism.  Continue to monitor.
   SEIZURE DISORDER -- continue kepra.  EEG to assess for non-convulsive
   status.
   SINUS DYSRHYTHMIA
 sinus pauses, no hemodynamic compromise.  Possible
   related to hilar mass, possible invovlement of conduction system.
   Possible vagal tone.  Monitor electrolytes.  Hold beta-blocker.
   Cardiology Consultation -- possible vagal response, and without need
   for specific intervention.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with poor mental status. He has a history of COPD and has developed right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for pneumonitis (VAP). He is receiving empirical antimicrobials and will be monitored for sputum culture and VAP treatment.

The patient has a complex medical history, including seizure disorder, adrenal insufficiency, hypoadosteronism, and SIADH, which may contribute to his hypotension and metabolic acidosis. He has a small cell carcinoma that is demonstrating clinical response to XRT and chemotherapy, but he needs further evaluation to define his prognosis.

The patient is at risk for various medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, and cardiac arrest. He requires close monitoring and management of his airway, oxygenation, and ventilation, as well as ongoing evaluation and treatment of his underlying medical conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on background of COPD. He is at risk for further respiratory compromise and failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has developed RLL and LLL infiltrates, concerning for pneumonitis (VAP), which may lead to sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of sinus dysrhythmia and is at risk for cardiac arrest due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
4. Renal failure: The patient has rising creatinine and falling urine output, which may indicate pre-renal or post-renal failure.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has persistent mild metabolic acidosis, which may be related to RTA secondary to hypoaldosteronism.
6. Seizure disorder: The patient has a seizure disorder and is at risk for further seizures due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
7. VAP: The patient has developed RLL and LLL infiltrates, concerning for pneumonitis (VAP), which may lead to further respiratory compromise and failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor ABG.
2. Monitor sputum and await culture.
3. Continue antimicrobials and monitor for VAP treatment.
4. Monitor electrolytes and hold beta-blocker.
5. Continue kepra and EEG to assess for non-convulsive status.
6. Monitor urine output and BUN, creatinine.
7. Monitor I/O and continue net hydration.
8. Monitor BP and maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg.
9. Continue steroids and monitor for tumor lysis.
10. Consider Neurological Consultation.

Note: The patient's complex medical history and multiple underlying conditions require a comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach to management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a diagnosis of multifactorial respiratory failure primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on the background of COPD. The patient also has new RLL and LLL infiltrates, concerning for pneumonitis (VAP), and is receiving empirical antimicrobials.

The patient's mental status is impaired, with a slow response to awakening and a history of seizure disorder. The patient is off Propofol and is undergoing EEG monitoring to assess for non-convulsive status epilepticus. The patient is also at risk for carcinomatous meningitis and is undergoing LP for CSF analysis.

The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, with a diagnosis of sinus dysrhythmia and possible involvement of the conduction system. The patient's electrolytes are being monitored, and beta-blocker therapy has been held.

The patient's renal status is concerning, with rising creatinine and falling urine output, possibly related to chemotherapy and recent contrast dye. The patient's metabolic acidosis is persistent and mild, possibly secondary to hypoaldosteronism.

The patient's nutritional status is being supported with TF, and their glycemic control is being monitored. The patient's anemia is stable, and they are at risk for tumor lysis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pneumonitis (VAP) progression and potential respiratory failure.
2. Carcinomatous meningitis and potential neurological complications.
3. Renal failure and potential need for dialysis.
4. Metabolic acidosis progression and potential need for intervention.
5. Tumor lysis syndrome and potential electrolyte imbalances.
6. Seizure disorder exacerbation and potential need for anticonvulsant therapy.
7. Sinus dysrhythmia progression and potential need for cardioversion.
8. Hypertension management and potential need for antihypertensive therapy.
9. Infection control measures to prevent further complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to address these potential complications and provide optimal care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a diagnosis of small cell carcinoma with SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and respiratory failure. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and has been off sedation for over 24 hours with poor mental status.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.8°C (100.1°F)
* Heart rate: 112 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 147/78 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient has a number of comorbidities, including COPD, anemia, and a seizure disorder. He is also receiving chemotherapy and radiation therapy for his cancer.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.0 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 29.6%
* Platelet count: 307 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Glucose: 160 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Respiratory failure
* Poor mental status
* Decreased muscle tone
* Grimacing to painful stimulus
* Warm, dry skin

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Mechanical ventilation
* Oxygen delivery device: Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Vt (Set): 430 mL
* RR (Set): 28
* PEEP: 8 cmH2O
* FiO2: 60%

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation
* Monitor ABG
* Monitor sputum, await culture
* Hope to eventually work towards SBT and extubation once completes VAP treatment and completes chemoRx and XRT
* Pneumonia treatment with antimicrobials
* Continue steroids for adrenal insufficiency
* Monitor BP and maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg
* Monitor I/O and continue net hydration
* Monitor urine output, BUN, and creatinine for renal failure
* Monitor electrolytes and consider Cardiology Consultation for sinus dysrhythmia
* Continue kepra for seizure disorder
* EEG to assess for non-convulsive status
* LP for CSF analysis for carcinomatous meningitis

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Renal failure
* Metabolic acidosis
* Hypertension
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hypophosphatemia
* Anemia
* Seizures
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* SVC syndrome
* Pericardial effusion
* Malignant pleural effusion
* Nutritional deficiencies

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings to prevent and manage these potential complications.

 4+ GNR, 2+ budding yeast, 2+ GPC in pairs, chains, clusters

   Granulocyte count- 790
   .
   CXR: No change in RUL mass; slight interval improvement in R basal
   consolidation
   CT head: No change from [**2172-8-28**].
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma, complicated by SVC syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She is currently intubated and ventilated, with a history of transient hypoxia, skin mottling, and bronchoscopy revealing ETT lodged between tracheal wall and Y-stent. Her respiratory status is complicated by possible underlying COPD, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases, and possible air stacking/trapping.

The patient has been on chemotherapy and radiation therapy for decompression, and is currently receiving neupogen for 10 days. She has acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, and is being managed accordingly. She also has a history of sinus pauses on telemetry, which have resolved, and is being monitored for any recurrence.

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 4.3
* Hct: 27.7
* Plt: 299
* Cr: 1.7
* TCO2: 19
* Glucose: 114
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 11.6/25.8/1.0, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T: 97/4/<0.01, ALT / AST: [**7-28**], Alk Phos / T Bili: 75/0.2, Differential-Neuts: 98.0 %, Band: 1.0 %, Lymph: 0.0 %, Mono: 1.0 %, Eos: 0.0 %, Fibrinogen: 641 mg/dL, Lactic Acid: 0.8 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.0 g/dL, LDH: 366 IU/L, Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.6 mg/dL, PO4: 5.0 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by possible underlying COPD, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases, and possible air stacking/trapping. She is at risk for respiratory failure and may require further interventions such as non-invasive ventilation or tracheostomy.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be exacerbated by chemotherapy and radiation therapy. She may require further interventions such as dialysis or renal replacement therapy.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as bicarbonate therapy or dialysis.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as hypertonic saline therapy or fluid restriction.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient has hyperkalemia, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as calcium gluconate therapy or potassium-lowering medications.
6. Sinus pauses: The patient has a history of sinus pauses on telemetry, which may recur. She may require further interventions such as transcutaneous pacing or dopamine therapy.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as antibiotic therapy or granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) therapy.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as blood transfusions or erythropoietin therapy.
9. SVC syndrome: The patient has SVC syndrome, which may be exacerbated by her underlying illness and chemotherapy. She may require further interventions such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for respiratory failure, acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, sinus pauses, leukocytosis, anemia, and SVC syndrome. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

   and metabolic acidosis despite increasing RR yesterday.  Peak pressures
   in the high 38-40 and plat pressures of 30 last night so decreased TV
   and increased RR to maintain same MV of 12 but to decrease airway
   pressures. Pressure decreased slightly with these changes with plat of
   25.  Her oxygenation was worse last night with saturation decreased to
   91%.  Her PEEP was increased.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.

   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP

   .

   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of

   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
