   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy and chemotherapy, now with respiratory failure,
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt still acidotic due to repiratory
   and metabolic acidosis, improved with HCO3 administration overnight.
   However pt with high RR requirement to compensate for acidosis with
   little room to increase RR. Numerous changes made to ventilator and
   tube placement yesterday.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, pulm
   edema as she required lots of fluids for hypotension,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR. Also with b/l pleural effusions seen on CT although tumor has
   decreased.
   -Vent: decrease tidal volumes as PIP high
   -Decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   -ABG to reassess oxygenation on new vent settings; goal pH > 7.2
   (7.2-7.24) with goal PaO2 >60.
   - holding vanc (for MRSA) as her level is elevated (therapeutic today);
   will check level in AM and readjust dose as needed
 continue holding
   today (d1 = [**2172-8-31**]; 8 day course)
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover pseudomonas VAP (Day 1= [**2172-8-31**];
   8 day course)
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy; scheduled for formal planning for XRT
   early next week (approx [**2172-9-8**])
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx; BAL results
   -bladder pressure [**Hospital1 **]
   -Possible bronch to evaluate tube placement
   -Goals of care (see below)
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol >72h and still
   not moving extremities or grossly following commands. Most likley toxic
   metabolic encephalopathy as pt is uremic. Differential includes seizure
   although EEG does not demonstrate seizure activity. LP does not
   demonstrate infection or spread of malignancy. CT head negative for
   acute process.
   - f/u  CSF studies
   -Will defer neuro consult at this time as it will most likely not
   change management
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: Pt now anuric. In setting of chemo with
   carboplatin.  Urine casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize SBP
   120s-130s but pt with hypotension. Now unable to give fluids as pt is
   volume overloaded, contributing to hypoxia.  Also, increased uric acid
   suggests possible TLS although usually seen 1-2d after chemo for SCC,
   here seen 4-5d post chemo.
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis: Now with respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   Received HCO3 last night so pH improved. Realize this is now a gap
   metabolic acidosis as her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is
   likely related to uremia.  Unable to increase RR due to concern for
   autopeeping in setting of possible COPD. Goal pH is 7.2-7.24.
   - will f/u endo and renal recs
   - If pH continues to decrease below 7.2, unable to give more HCO3 as it
   requires much fluid and pt is fluid overloaded.
   .
   # Tachycardia/Hypotension with new [**Name (NI) 7929**]
 Pt with continued
   tachycardia and episodes of hypotension. EKG demonstrated new onset
   A-fib. LENIs negative for DVT but unable to assess for PE as pt cannot
   have CTA given renal failure and VQ scan will not be helpful in setting
   of lung pathology. Echo did not show RV strain or enlarging pericardial
   effusion. Per Hem/Onc, no anti-coagulation as tumor may hemorrhage.
   Also may have increased SVC compression with decreased preload.
   -F/u Hem/Onc re: chemo and XRT (currently scheduled for approx [**2172-9-8**])
   -[**Month (only) 11**] do small fluid boluses for hypotension although pt with pulm edema
   until d/w family
   .
   #. Electrolyte disturbances: Hypernatremia resolved after D5W
   administration. Pt had hyponatremia and hyperkalemia on admission, both
   resolved. Unclear etiology of electrolyte disturbances on admission-
   thought to be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now
   discarded) or possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal
   recommends rechecking urine lytes with saline load, not yet done in
   setting of pt
s other medical issues.  (In SIADH, UNa should increase
   and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   -F/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] and renin
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   Pt was to have formal tissue planning session early this week (approx
   [**2172-9-8**]).
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
 per Hem/Onc, decreased WBC ct
   in setting of neupogen does not bode well.
   - f/u heme/onc recs and rad/onc recs
   - continue neutropenic precautions
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Seen in appoximately 10%
   cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared to admission. Per
   family, pt did not have SVC syndrome when she came to hospital ([**Hospital Unit Name 10**]
   team thought she had it on presentation to ED). SVC syndrome occurred
   after Y-stent placed. Possible that tumor pushing into trachea shifted
   to compress SVC after stent placement.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   -F/u Hem/Onc recs
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**]. Had new episodes within last few days, again with
   turning.  Resumed beat is junctional. Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - Care with turning patient
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - Per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, no pressors if resumed
   beat is wide complex.
   .
   #Leukopenia/thrombocytopenia
 most likely due to chemotherapy. Pt on
   neupogen with continued decreased counts. Per Onc, this does not bode
   well for prognosis. Low suspicion for HITT.
   -D/c heparin SC
   -F/u hem/onc recs
   -Trend CBC
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. Per
   ECHO [**2172-9-5**], effusion not increased. No tamponade.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC,
   but labs WNL. ACD possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   .
   #Goals of care: discuss with family that pt is in multisystem organ
   failure and prognosis is poor.

   Disposition: ICU<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still experiencing respiratory acidosis and hypoxia, which may worsen if not properly managed. The patient's high RR requirement and high PIP may indicate air stacking or trapping, which can further exacerbate respiratory failure.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and urine output is decreased, indicating AKI. The patient's fluid overload and electrolyte disturbances may worsen AKI.
3. Electrolyte disturbances: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, but hyponatremia and hyperkalemia may still be present. The patient's low UNa and high Uosm suggest possible SIADH, which may require further evaluation and management.
4. Tachycardia and hypotension: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be related to SVC syndrome, hypovolemia, or other underlying conditions. The patient's EKG shows new onset A-fib, which may require further evaluation and management.
5. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's decreased WBC and platelet counts may be related to chemotherapy, and the patient's prognosis may be poor if these counts do not improve.
6. Malignant effusion: The patient's pleural effusion and pericardial effusion may be malignant, which may require further evaluation and management.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and hypoxia may be related to pneumonia, which may require further evaluation and management.
8. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension may indicate sepsis, which may require further evaluation and management.
9. Multi-organ failure: The patient's respiratory, renal, and cardiovascular failure may indicate multi-organ failure, which may require further evaluation and management.

The patient's goals of care should be discussed with the family, and palliative care consult may be necessary to address the patient's poor prognosis. The patient's DNR status should be respected, and the family should be informed of the patient's condition and prognosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo f with respiratory failure in setting of newly diagnosed lung ca
   (likely small cell) c/b SVC syndrome (partial compression), airway
   compromise (requiring Y-stent) admitted for xrt and chemotherapy now
   with progressive clinical decline and MODS.
   Issues include:
          Resp failure
          Large lung mass (likely small cell), airway collapse, R
   effusion
          Svc syndrome
          R pnx (CT in palce with lung reinflated)
          VAP
          Decreased level of consciousness/unresponsiveness off
   sedation
          Tachycardia
atrial fib
          Hypotension
          ARF
          Thrombocytopenia/pancytopenia
          Hypernatremia (resolved)
   Pt is in MODS with underlying aggressive lung malignancy  and shows
   continued clinical decline.  Her prognosis is extremely poor.  We
   continue to update family regarding worsening status and to address
   goals of care who fully understand her critical condition.
   Pt
s respiratory failure is multifactorial, [**2-10**]
   malpositioning/migration of ETT between stent and tracheal wall,
   extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi [**2-10**]
   lung mass, probable underlying COPD, and RLL and LLL (retrocardiac)
   infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (VAP), plugging.  She remains
   tachy in afib and hypotensive.  At this time we are limited as to
   options to further temporize.  Giving additional fluids is contributing
   to volume overload with third spacing and tense abd distention in
   setting of progressive renal decline (progressively anuric), further
   impacting her resp status, now with increasing O2 needs and high airway
   presssures.  She remains unresponsive off sedation X days, likely toxic
   metabolic from uremia and infection.  Work up with eeg, LP, and head ct
   has been unrevealing.
   --We will stop fluids and compensate as able with vent.
   --We will check bladder pressures for compartment syndome
   --Dialysis would further prolong course in this patient and is unlikely
   to change to her overall prognosis.
   --Continue ACV support.  We will decrease her TV to lower pips/plts and
   accept ph > 7.2, Decrease fio2 and accept pao2 > 65.
    --We have discussed and evaluated for a broad ddx of her a-fib and
   hypotension (including infection, tension PTX, PE, rv compression from
   mass/decreasing CO and preload from mass, cardiac tamponade and cardiac
   ischemia).   This appears mutlifactorial and largely related to
   underlying infection and lung mass.
   -- We continue empiric antiibx (vanco,cipro,cef).
   Remainder as per resident note.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2172-9-5**] 03:41 AM 10 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2172-8-26**] 01:00 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2172-8-26**] 03:37 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots(Systemic anticoagulation: sq hep held for low plts)
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 40 minutes
   Patient is critically ill
   Addendum
   Following am rounds, I spoke with pt
s son by phone and updated him as
   to his mother
s condition and continued decline. Explained that we are
   very limited as additional fluids are contributing to worsening
   oxygenation and significant volume overload in setting of progressive
   renal failure.  Without fluids, she is becoming progressively
   hypotensive.  We are now maxing out in terms of ventilator on 100%
   FIO2.   She remains unresponsive off all sedation. Her prognosis for
   recovery remains extremely poor and she is declining despite our
   aggressive attempts.  Pt
s son expressed his full understanding.  All
   of his questions were answered.  At this time he wishes to move toward
   CMO with terminal extubation understanding that his mother will likely
   pass quickly after removal of the ETT.  We will focus fully on her
   comfort with morphine as needed.  His uncle is headed in and he will
   let us know if his uncle wishes to be present at the time of
   extubation.  He and pt
s sisters and other family member spent time at
   bedside yesterday and do not plan to be present.
   Additional 20 minutes crit care time spent in discussion.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to a newly diagnosed lung cancer, likely small cell, and SVC syndrome. She has a large compressing lung mass, airway compromise, and progressive bilateral opacities with pulmonary edema, pleural effusions, and stable right upper lobe opacification.

The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with worsening respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. She has also developed thrombocytopenia and pancytopenia. The patient is in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) with a poor prognosis.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, with malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube (ETT), extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, and probable underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She also has right and left lower lobe infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (ventilator-associated pneumonia, VAP).

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Stopping fluids and compensating as able with the ventilator.
2. Checking bladder pressures for compartment syndrome.
3. Not initiating dialysis, as it would prolong the patient's course without improving her prognosis.
4. Continuing acetate-citrate-dextrose (ACV) support and adjusting the ventilator settings to lower peak inspiratory pressures (PIPs) and plateaus.
5. Decreasing the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) and accepting a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) greater than 65.
6. Empiric antibiotic therapy (vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and cefipime).
7. Focusing on the patient's comfort with morphine as needed.

The patient's family has been informed of her poor prognosis and has expressed a desire to move towards comfort care with terminal extubation. The patient's son has been updated on her condition and has expressed understanding of her situation. The patient's uncle will be notified of the plan to extubate her, and the family does not plan to be present at the time of extubation.

   She is in MOSF with underlying aggressive malignancy with poor
   prognosis and continued decline.  We continue to update family
   regarding worsening status and to address goals of care.   We are
   limited as to options to further temporize.  Giving additional fluids
   is contributing to worsening oxygenation and thrid spacing and
   distneded tense abd.  Will stop fluids and compensate as able with
   vent.   Dialysis would furtehr prolong course in this patient and is
   unlikely to change to overall prognosis. Pngong goals of care to be
   addressed with family on update
   Pt
s respiratory failure is multifactorial, [**2-10**]
   malpositioning/migration of ETT between stent and tracheal wall,
   extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi [**2-10**]
   lung mass, probable underlying COPD, and RLL and LLL (retrocardiac)
   infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (VAP), plugging. She is now more
   volume overloaded on higher fio2 and now with higher pressures.  Her
   belly is more tesne and she is nearly anuric.  We continue empiric
   antiibx (vanco,cipro,cef) following vanco levels as she has multifocal
   pna and post-obstructive pna.  Continue ACV support, adjusting MV to
   optimize pH as able.  Her PIPS/plkts are high
we will decrease her TV
   and accept ph > 7.2, can lower fio2 and accept pao2 > 65.  R CT remains
   in position while on MV.  Fluid overload/anuria is further contributing
   to her resp status
will stop bicarb gtt and check bladder pressures.
   She remains tachy and hypotensive. DDX includes--? new infection (on
   broad empiric coverage),  tension pnx, progression of pericardial
   effusion/tamponade and PE.   Bolus IVF, stat ecg as rate appears
   irregular, repeat cxr, and d/w cards repeat echo to assess for
   tamponade.  Pt is poor candidate for empiric antbx given necrotic tumor
   and thrombocytopenia and would hold on CTA gven ARF.  TEE may offer
   additional info regarding RV fx/.  Will also [**Doctor Last Name **] LENIs.  Pan cx. Trend
   lactates., given underlying lung process, her dead space fraction will
   be high and this is unlikely to clarify PE issue.  Her TTE at bedside
   on prelim does not suggest tamponade, rv failure.  Issues of worsening
   compression and decreased preload may also be eeffcting her pressures.
   She remains unresponsive, now off Propofol X 3 days.  Repeat head CT
   unrevealing. MRI not possible due to presence of intracranial surgical
   clips.  No evidence of sz on eeg. No evidence for carcinomatous
   meningitis by LP.  Likely most c/w toxic metabolic encephalopathy with
   component of uremia. Follow neuro exam.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to small cell lung cancer (SCLC) with suspected SVC syndrome, airway compromise, and right-sided effusion. The patient has a poor prognosis and is critically ill.

The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with worsening respiratory failure, increased oxygen requirements, and decreased urine output. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a cuff leak and is experiencing acidosis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 0.1 K/uL
* Hct: 26.8%
* Plt: 38 K/uL
* Cr: 2.7 mg/dL
* TCO2: 20 mmol/L
* Glucose: 177 mg/dL
* Lactic Acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.8 g/dL
* LDH: 366 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.6 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.5 mg/dL
* PO4: 7.2 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Et high, progressive bilateral opacities, fluid, and pna
* TTE: Preliminary report suggests no RV strain, unchanged pericardial effusion

The patient's medical issues include:

* Respiratory failure
* Small cell lung cancer with suspected SVC syndrome
* Airway compromise
* Right-sided effusion
* VAP
* Altered mental status
* Tachycardia
* Hypotension
* ARF
* Thrombocytopenia
* Hypernatremia
* Altered mental status
* Pancytopenia

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing empiric antibiotics for multifocal pneumonia
* Adjusting mechanical ventilation to optimize pH
* Decreasing TV and accepting pH > 7.2
* Lowering FiO2 and accepting PaO2 > 65
* Stopping bicarbonate gtt and checking bladder pressures
* Bolus IVF and stat ECG for irregular rate
* Repeat CXR and d/w cards for repeat echo to assess for tamponade
* TEE may offer additional information regarding RV function

The patient's prognosis is poor, and further temporization is limited. The family has been updated regarding the patient's worsening status, and goals of care are being addressed.
